ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I had very little understanding of the history and development of right-wing-ideology throughout history.

I learned a lot in this course, as we covered many tenets of the Right I had not been exposed to before. The seminar format also allowed me to learn beyond the readings by hearing what my classmates understood from the content. I also really enjoyed the way the topics progressed as they seemed to build upon each other and we were able to reference earlier classes.
I learned a lot about analyzing how ideology changes over time.
I learned a lot about the main strains of thought that define the global right. I learned how to connect such characteristic right-wing ideologies across different cultures and political parties

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Nothing more to be improved on.
I didnt find any weaknesses with the course. I found the seminar format to work very well with the content and found the reading and assignments to be engaging and manageable.

Strengths: The discussions. Professor Stern does a great job of leading the discussions and the topics can lead to some really interesting conversations. 

Weaknesses: Some of the readings were dry and some of the readings were a lot, such as assigning a whole book or several books for a discussion.

Having the course be student-led definitely had its strengths and weaknesses. I enjoyed when students asked questions of their peers; this allows for more interesting and free-flowing discussion. Sometimes, however, people would just sum up the readings, and we wouldn't really have class discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I have recommended this course to my friends already, and would to any person who is interested in learning about the Right. It was a unique opportunity to understand conservatism beyond just political party and what many associate with that.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in studying political ideologies.

I would recommend this course to people interested in learning more about the global right and how it has defined itself across time and political movements. Students looking for a robust seminar with discussions have to be pretty proactive in this class; otherwise, the professor tends to talk a lot about/summarize the reading material.
